did.unittitle: Radio Club and Student Radio Stations records

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Radio Club and Student Radio Stations

did.abstract: Records of the Radio Club include correspondence, program schedules, histories, photographs and subject files pertaining to the founding and operation of WCSR. The Student Radio Station Records include fliers, advertising, promotional items and publications of WOZQ, Smith's current student run radio station.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for use without restriction beyond the standard terms and conditions of Smith College Special Collections.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The records of the Radio Club and Student Radio Stations files were donated by members of the radio stations over a period of time.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into two series: Series I (WCSR) and Series II (WOZQ)

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The first meeting of the Radio Club was held on December 2, 1947. Marjorie Boselly was appointed by the President of the Student Council to conduct research on the possibility of starting a student-run radio station at Smith. Their goals were to provide Smith students with a radio program that related to their particular interests, to integrate curricular and extra-curricular activities on campus, and to give interested young women practical experience in the field of radio. After just over a year of research, lectures, training, and convincing, Boselly's vision was realized as WCSR, the radio station. WCSR went on the air for the first time on January 6, 1949. Although the Radio Club was at first housed in a college-owned garage and was broadcast over the electric power line which followed the central heating system, it received tremendous support from the student body. It was not long before WCSR began to flourish. In the spring of 1950, WCSR joined Amherst College's WAMF and the University of Massachusetts' WMUA in the Pioneer Broadcasting System. By doing so WCSR participated in larger-scale broadcasts and combined the talents and interests of students from all three schools.

Throughout its years of existence, WCSR aired many different types of programs ranging from evenings of classical music to disc-jockey shows to dramas to interviews to campus debates and always played special shows on holidays. Club members had high hopes for the future of radio. Their plans for improvement were put on hold indefinitely when the building in which WCSR was housed had to be torn down in 1956. These ideas and plans were not revived until twenty-one years later, when in 1977 WRSC, a new radio station, was created in an attempt to ease communication problems that had arisen on campus. As college radio stations in general began to flourish during the early 1980's, the radio station went FM in 1982 as WOZQ, playing twenty-four hours a day, seven days a week. The staff of WOZQ describes itself as "student run and estrogen powered" and prides itself in playing music to suit an array of different tastes and hosting shows at various locations throughout the Pioneer Valley.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Please use the following format when citing materials from this collection:
Radio Club and Student Radio Stations Records, Box #, Smith College Archives, CA-MS-00094, Smith College Special Collections, Northampton, Massachusetts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Records of the Radio Club include correspondence, program schedules, histories, photographs and subject files pertaining to the founding and operation of WCSR. The Student Radio Station Records include fliers, advertising, promotional items and publications of WOZQ, Smith's current student run radio station.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Smith College retains copyright of materials created as part of its business operations; however, copyright in other items in this collection may be held by their respective creators. For reproductions of materials that are governed by fair use as defined under U. S. Copyright Law, no permission to cite or publish is required. For instances which may regard materials in the collection not created by Smith College, researchers are responsible for determining who may hold materials' copyrights and obtaining approval from them. Researchers do not need anything further from Smith College Special Collections to move forward with their use.

did.unittitle: Series II. Student Run Radio Stations (WOZQ)
